As a result of this, in larger wars your army will for the main part consist of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Core Units[COLOR_REVERT], because these can be produced in great numbers once your [LINK=CONCEPT_GUNS]Military Industry[\LINK] gathers stamina. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Core Units[COLOR_REVERT] that are available for European Nations in this game are: Scouts, Colonial Militia, Line Infantry, Dragoons, Cavalrymen as well as Light and Heavy Artillery. Braves, Armed Braves, Mounted Braves and Armed Mounted Braves are available for native nations only.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Note that most of these units are [LINK=CONCEPT_PROFESSIONS]Professions[\LINK] that can be given to colonists (or [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]natives[\LINK]), not units in their own right. For each military profession, units will perform better if they are [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Veteran Soldiers[COLOR_REVERT]. That means that each of the military professions has ist own special veteran unit that serves at its best if it is put into its corresponding profession. The veteran units are the [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]seasoned Scout[\LINK], the [LINK=UNIT_VETERAN_INFANTRY]Veteran Infantry Soldiers[\LINK], the [LINK=UNIT_VETERAN_DRAGOON]Veteran Dragoon[\LINK] and the [LINK=UNIT_VETERAN_CAVALRY]Veteran Cavalryman[\LINK]. The [LINK=UNIT_LIGHT_ARTILLERY_VETERAN]Light Artillery and Heavy Artillery[\LINK] are units and not professions. Light and Heavy Artillery can be produced in the colonies if certain requirements are fulfilled (e.g. special buildings are required) or they can be acquired in Europe.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Elite Units[COLOR_REVERT] that are available in this game are: [LINK=UNIT_RANGER]Rangers[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_NATIVE_MERC] Native Mercenaries [\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_CONQUISTADOR]Conquistadores[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_MOUNTED_CONQUISTADOR]Mounted Conquistadores [\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_MORTAR]Mortars[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_CONTINENTAL_GUARD]Continental Guards[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_HESSIAN]Hessians[\LINK] und [LINK=UNIT_MILITIA]Settler Militias[\LINK]. The Line Infantry has an exceptional position. The [LINK=UNIT_EUROPEAN_LINE_INFANTRY]European Line Infantry[\LINK] is an Elite Unit, which can be acquired in Europe only, whereas the Colonial Line Infantry is a military profession of the Core Units in the New World. The veteran unit is also the [LINK=UNIT_VETERAN_INFANTRY]Veteran Infantry Soldier[\LINK]. The Colonial Line Infantry can be hired in the New World but cannot be acquired in Europe. However, both units have the same strength. Of course the player will have the chance to get some of the units frequently, whereas some of the units are rare. In general the Elite Units will be achieved by special (diplomatic) [LINK=CONCEPT_EVENTS]Events[\LINK] with the own king, kings of other nations or native leaders as long as the player is not at war with this parties. Furthermore the [LINK=CONCEPT_CHURCH]Church[\LINK] will sometimes grant some units as well in case the player is willing to declare war on a (heretical) native nation. Finally also some of the [LINK=CONCEPT_FATHERS]Founding Fathers[\LINK] will grant troops, in case they can be convinced to hook up with the own colonies.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Combat, Experience and Generals[\BOLD]Individual units gain Combat Experience if they win [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Battles[\LINK], and they can achieve [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]Promotions[\LINK] this way. If your units gather enough Combat Experience, [LINK=CONCEPT_GREAT_GENERALS]Great Generals[\LINK] may be born in your colonies, who give your units Combat Bonuses, extra Experience and access to several promotions that are otherwise unreachable.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]The different Military Units[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=PROFESSION_SCOUT]Scouts[\LINK][\BOLD] - These units require only [LINK=YIELD_HORSES]Horses[\LINK] to be equipped, and they give additional [LINK=CONCEPT_MOVEMENT]Movement Speed[\LINK]. Scouts are relatively week, so they usually aren't useful in combat against units stronger than [LINK=CONCEPT_ANIMALS]Wild Animals[\LINK]. Their main purpose is [LINK=CONCEPT_VISIBILITY]Exploration[\LINK]. After they have explored the New World they can be used as stron military units (change of specialisation will be required) since they should have collected a lot of [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]promotions[\LINK] in the meantime due to their journey through the New World - in case they have survived this journey.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=UNIT_CONQUISTADOR]Conquistadores[\LINK][\BOLD] and [LINK=UNIT_MOUNTED_CONQUISTADOR]Mounted Conquistadores[\LINK][\BOLD] - These Elite Units can be acquired through multiple means: exploring [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_GOODY_HUT2]Ancient Ruins[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_FATHERS]Founding Fathers[\LINK] as well as a [LINK=CONCEPT_EVENTS]Random Diplomatic Event[\LINK], as long as you are at war with a Native Tribe. The [LINK=CONCEPT_CHURCH]Archbishop[\LINK] may provide you with some of these units as well, when he urges you to exterminate a particular Native tribe. Conquistadores get a bonus against all [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Melee Units[COLOR_REVERT] (including other Conquistadores), and a combat bonus against [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Native Mercenaries[COLOR_REVERT] as well. As such, they are primarily useful for waging wars against Natives, who employ mainly Melee units. Other disciplined European military units are generally too strong for the Conquistadores. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=UNIT_RANGER]Ranger[\LINK][\BOLD] - Rangers are rare Elite Units that are experts in fighting in the Wilderness. They get a Combat Bonus when fighting in Forests and Jungles, both when attacking and defending. On top of that, they are [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Invisible[COLOR_REVERT] to nearly all enemy units (except natives, other Ranger or native mercenaries), which makes them particularly useful as Commandoes in hostile territory.[NEWLINE]Rangers can be acquired through [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Diplomatic Events[COLOR_REVERT] in which your King offers you to buy these units, and are also provided by certain [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Founding Fathers[COLOR_REVERT]. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=UNIT_NATIVE_MERC]Native Mercenaries[\LINK][\BOLD] - Native Mercenaries are Elite Units that can fight exceptionally well in the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Wilderness[COLOR_REVERT], just like Rangers. The difference between these two is that, while Rangers get a solid [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Combat Bonus[COLOR_REVERT] in Forests both on attack and on defense, while Native Mercenaries only get [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Attack Bonuses[COLOR_REVERT] in the Wilderness, although these are much higher than the bonuses the Ranger gets. These Attack Bonuses are equal to the attack bonuses [LINK= PROFESSION_BRAVE]Natives[\LINK] have. Native Mercenaries can be found in places like [LINK=CONCEPT_GOODY_HUT]Burial Grounds[\LINK], they can be offered to you by [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Native Tribes[COLOR_REVERT], and they are provided by some [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Founding Fathers[COLOR_REVERT] as well. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=UNIT_MILITIA]Settler Militia[\LINK][\BOLD] - Though Settler Militias are technically Elite Units, as you cannot build them yourself, they are pretty weak for Gunpowder units, having only a low combat strength. They are generated when a [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Colony[COLOR_REVERT] feels unprotected due to a lack of military units, for which they take [LINK=YIELD_FOOD]Food[\LINK] from their food stores and money from your treasury. Though Settler Militias are rather weak, they do get a [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Defense Bonus[COLOR_REVERT] when defending a settlement, which allows them to successfully fight off weaker attacks such as Native Raids. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=PROFESSION_COLONIAL_MILITIA]Colonial Militia[\LINK][\BOLD] - Colonial Militias are the weakest but cheapest standard military unit. They are well trained infantry troops which can be used for attack and defense. Colonial Militias are your basic Gunpowder units in the New World. Almost all colonist can adopt this profession, as long as there are [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Guns[COLOR_REVERT] present to equip them. They are stronger than most Melee units. In the wilderness they may have some disadvantages against native warriors, so be careful using them in the wilderness against natives until they have reached veteran status by combat! Veteran Infantry soliders (in the profession Colonial Militia) can be hired in Europe as well and some Founding Fathers will grant them as well.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=PROFESSION_LINE_INFANTRY]Line Infantry[\LINK][\BOLD] - The Colonial Line Infantry is the strongest infantry unit in the game and is well trained for war. The Colonial Infantry can be hired and equipped in the colonies, since it is a profession, as far as enough weapons ([LINK=YIELD_MUSKETS]muskets[\LINK] and [LINK=YIELD_BLADES]blades[\LINK] are stored in the colony that intends to equip the infantry. The colonial infantry cannot be hired in Europe. The Colonial Line Infantry can get Veteran status after a while. However, alternatively the [LINK=UNIT_EUROPEAN_LINE_INFANTRY]European Line Infantry[\LINK] can be hired in Europe. The European Line Infantry is a military unit with the same strength as the Colonial Line Infantry. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=PROFESSION_DRAGOON]Dragoons[\LINK][\BOLD] - Dragoons are mounted infantry units. [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Mounted Units[COLOR_REVERT] are units who wage war while sitting on horseback. They are faster than other units and have the same strength as colonial militia, but they do not get [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Defensive Bonuses[COLOR_REVERT], which makes them rather weak when not fighting in the open field. You can make Dragoons by equipping colonists with both [LINK=YIELD_HORSES]Horses[\LINK] and [LINK=YIELD_MUSKETS]Guns[\LINK]. They get a movement bonus. Veteran Dragoons automatically get the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Leadership[COLOR_REVERT] Promotion, which doubles the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Experience Points[COLOR_REVERT] they earn by winning Battles. So if you want to thoroughly train your soldiers in combat, letting them fight as Dragoons is an excellent method. In addition to this, Dragoons also receive a bonus when attacking [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Artillery Units[COLOR_REVERT] which makes them to be a strong unit against all artillery units. Dragoons can either be ecquipped in the colonies or they can be hired in Europe if enough money is in the treasury of the player. In the end the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]cost-value ratio of a Dragoon is excellent[COLOR_REVERT] which makes them very usefull military units. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=PROFESSION_HEAVY_CAVALRY]Heavy Calavry[\LINK][\BOLD] - Cavalrymen are the strongest Mounted Units you can make. The Heavy Cavalry is a military profession as well. To make them, equip a colonist with [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Horses, Guns and Blades[COLOR_REVERT]. Heavy Cavalry can be hired in Europe as well. They have a high combat strength, but they have a movement of only 1, which makes them slower than other Mounted Units. Due to their high combat strength, Cavalrymen can be useful in all kinds of Warfare, whether in the fields, attacking settlements or defending them. However, in the wilderness they may have some disadvantages against other units. .[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=UNIT_CONTINENTAL_GUARD]Continental Guards [\LINK][\BOLD]and [BOLD][LINK=UNIT_HESSIAN]Hessians[\LINK][\BOLD] - These two units are very rare military units - don't hazard them! Continental Guards are Elite Units that can be acquired later in the game, as you prepare for [LINK=CONCEPT_INDEPENDENCE_WAR]Independence[\LINK]. They are offered to you by [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Foreign Kings[COLOR_REVERT], who might be inclined to make these offers if your [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Diplomatic Relations[\LINK] with their colonies is good.[NEWLINE]Continental Guards have a very high combat strength, but you recruit them with four promotions already present: [LINK=PROMOTION_VETERAN1]Veteran I[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_VETERAN2]Veteran II[\LINK], [LINK=PROMOTION_BAYONET]Bayonet[\LINK] and [LINK=PROMOTION_LEADERSHIP]Leadership[\LINK]. Additionally, they receive a combat bonus against other [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Gunpowder Units[COLOR_REVERT]. These units are very strong, and can be essential to the success of your War of Independence. Hessians are [LINK=CONCEPT_EUROPE]European[\LINK] Elite Units that appear in great numbers in your King's [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Royal Expeditionary Force[COLOR_REVERT]. You can get a few of these units as well though, through some [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Founding Fathers[COLOR_REVERT] or as reinforcements sent by your King to conquer other colonies. Hessians do not receive defensive bonuses, but they get a combat bonus when [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]attacking Settlements[COLOR_REVERT] and attacking in open fields, as well as the Veteran I, Leadership and Bayonet promotions which makes them a very strong unit.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD][LINK=UNIT_LIGHT_ARTILLERY_VETERAN]Light Artillery [\LINK][\BOLD] and [BOLD][LINK=UNIT_HEAVY_ARTILLERY_VETERAN]Heavy Artillery[\LINK][\BOLD] - These two artillery respectively siege units are your basic artilley in the New World. Artillery ans Siege Units are units that deploy [LINK=YIELD_CANNONS]Cannons[\LINK] to wage war against their enemies. Except for the Light Artillery, none of them get any [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Defensive Bonuses[COLOR_REVERT]. Light Artillery is the cheapest [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Siege Unit[COLOR_REVERT] available, and the only one to receive Defensive Bonuses. They also receive a [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Settlement Defense[COLOR_REVERT] bonus. This makes them able defenders of your settlements, though offensive Siege Units like Heavy Artillery will usually be stronger. Light Artillery can be recruited in [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Europe[COLOR_REVERT], where they are the cheapest units available, and they can also be produced in Settlements with an [LINK=BUILDING_ARMORY]Armory[\LINK] or one of its upgrades. Heavy Artillery is your primary unit when it comes to [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Attacking Settlements[COLOR_REVERT]. They can also [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Bombard[COLOR_REVERT] the defenses of enemy settlements to weaken them, before moving in for the kill. Heavy Artillery can be recruited in [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Europe[COLOR_REVERT] as well, and they can also be built in settlements with a [LINK=BUILDING_MAGAZINE]Magazine[\LINK] or one of its upgrades. There exists one other rare and heavy artillery unit: [LINK=UNIT_MORTAR]Mortars[\LINK][\BOLD] - Mortars are Elite Units that can be offered to you by [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Foreign Kings[COLOR_REVERT] if you have good relations with their colonies, just like [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Continental Guards[COLOR_REVERT]. When attacking settlements, they are even stronger than Heavy Artillery, because they start with the [LINK=PROMOTION_BOMBI]Explosives I[\LINK] promotion, but they truly excel in [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Bombarding[COLOR_REVERT] the fortifications of enemy settlements, reducing their Defensive Bonuses by 30% each turn. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Native Warrios[\BOLD] - Of course the Native Nations do not have any access tot he above named military units. They have their own [BOLD][LINK=PROFESSION_BRAVE]Braves[\LINK][\BOLD]. These melee warriors are only available to [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Natives[COLOR_REVERT]. They are relatively weak, but they get attack bonuses when attacking units in [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_FOREST]Forests[\LINK] or [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_JUNGLE]Jungles[\LINK]. When native tribes are at war, they usually send swarms of countless braves to the lands of their foes. [BOLD][LINK=PROFESSION_ARMED_BRAVE]Armed Braves[\LINK][\BOLD] are their gunpowder unit. Only Natives can make Armed Braves. These are stronger unitsand they also get the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Attack Bonuses[COLOR_REVERT] of normal Braves when attacking units in the Wilderness. This can make them perticularly tough foes. They only require half as much [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Guns[COLOR_REVERT] as Colonial Militias, which means that Natives can equip several Armed Braves once they get their hands on Guns. However, they are not as strong as European colonial troops in the open field. Once Natives manage to get some Horses, they can equip warriors with horses to make [LINK=PROFESSION_MOUNTED_BRAVE]Mounted Braves[\LINK]. These are faster than regular Braves. Mounted Braves require only half as much [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Horses[COLOR_REVERT] to be equipped as European Mounted troops. [BOLD][LINK=PROFESSION_ARMED_MOUNTED_BRAVE]Armed Mounted Braves[\LINK][\BOLD] are the strongest units Natives can bring in the field. They require both guns and horses, though only half the amounts of them that a dragoon would require. They have a high combat strength and, combined with their attack bonuses when attacking units in the wilderness, they can be a plague to colonial invaders in any terrain.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Other Melee Units[\BOLD] - [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Wild Animals[COLOR_REVERT] are Melee units as well, just like non-military units like [LINK=PROFESSION_COLONIST]Colonists[\LINK], [LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Pioneers[\LINK] and [LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]Missionaries[\LINK].

TEXT.English: Missionaries
TEXT.German: Missionare

TEXT.English: [H1]MISSIONARIES[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Missionaries[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]Missionaries[\LINK] are special [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]units[\LINK] who can establish [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]missions[COLOR_REVERT] in [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]Native[\LINK] [LINK=CONCEPT_SETTLEMENTS]settlements[\LINK], work in [LINK=CONCEPT_MONASTERIES]monasteries[\LINK] or [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]incite[COLOR_REVERT] Native warriors to raid their European neighbours. Over time, missions and [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MONASTERY]monasteries[\LINK] will create [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]converted Natives[\LINK], who you can employ in your colonies as expert - and free - raw materials producers or mediocre manufactured goods producers.[PARAGRAPH:1]The establishment of the first mission is always easy. Later, the probability of success with the same Indigenous nation decreases with every new mission that you set up. Failure to establish a mission also puts a strain on diplomatic relations with this Indigenous nation. However, successful establishment of a mission also improves it.[PARAGRAPH:1]Before you can build a mission, you must first create a missionary. You assign a colonist to this [LINK=CONCEPT_PROFESSIONS]profession[\LINK] from the settlement screen, by double-clicking the preferred colonist and selecting [LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]missionary[\LINK] from the list of available professions, or by moving a unit onto the same tile as one of your settlements on the main game screen and selecting [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]"Change Profession"[COLOR_REVERT].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Missions[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]After giving a colonist the missionary profession, your new missionary will travel outside the colony. Your missionary can enter a Native village and press the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]"Create Mission"[COLOR_REVERT] button, which will consume the missionary. Doing this with a [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]Jesuit missionary[\LINK] or an [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY_PROT]evangelist[\LINK] will greatly increase the rate at which new [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]converted Natives[\LINK] are created.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Failure to Convert[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1] If, however, your missionary fails to convert the village, he may suffer a crisis of faith and become disillusioned. His profession will change to colonist and he will be unable to resume missionary work even after returning to a settlement, though a Jesuit or evangelist will still generate extra crosses in a chapel or its upgrades.[PARAGRAPH:1]If a mission from another European colony already exists in an Indian village, you can displace it with your own missionary, converting the residents to your own faith. Of course the competition can also do that to you. Replacing an existing mission does not improve relationships with its owner.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Monasteries[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]A colonist with the missionary profession can also work in a monastery. Monasteries are built by [LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]pioneers[\LINK], and they become functional when a missionary is in residence. For more information, see the [LINK=CONCEPT_MONASTERIES]Monasteries[\LINK] concept.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Stirring Up Natives[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Missionaries are able to [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]stir up natives[COLOR_REVERT] in a village. This can happen only one time per village.[PARAGRAPH:1]Stirring up natives will make some young warriors go [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]raiding[COLOR_REVERT] against the land-stealing settlers. But be careful! They might choose [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]your own colonies[COLOR_REVERT] as the target, if you aren't careful where you stir them up.
TEXT.French: [H1]MISSIONAIRES[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Les missionnaires sont des explorateurs spéciaux qui peuvent fonder des "missions" dans les villages [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]indigènes[\LINK]. Avec le temps, ces missions créeront des [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]indigènes convertis[\LINK], que vous pourrez employer gratuitement dans vos colonies comme producteurs expérimentés de matières premières ou comme producteurs médiocres de produits manufacturés.[PARAGRAPH:2]Avant de créer une mission, vous devez créer un missionnaire. Vous pouvez attribuer cette [LINK=CONCEPT_PROFESSIONS]profession[\LINK] à un colon depuis l'écran de village, en effectuant un [double-clic] sur le colon et en sélectionnant Missionnaire dans la liste des professions disponibles, ou en déplaçant une unité vers une case occupée par l'une de vos colonies sur l'écran principal et sélectionner l'ordre Changer de profession. [PARAGRAPH:2]Lorsque vous avez attribué la profession de missionnaire à un colon, celui-ci quitte la colonie. Vous pouvez alors le guider vers un village [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]indigène[\LINK] et cliquer sur le bouton Créer une mission (le missionnaire sera détruit). Si vous procédez ainsi avec un [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]missionnaire jésuite[\LINK], les [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]indigènes convertis[\LINK] seront créés beaucoup plus vite.[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Provoquer les Indianes[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Les missionnaires peuvent semer le trouble chez les indigènes. Cela ne peut se faire qu'une fois par village. En agitant les indiens, quelques jeunes indiens mèneront des raids contre les visages pâles. Mais attention, ils pourraient choisir vos propres colonies comme cible, si vous n'y prêtez pas attention.
TEXT.German: [H1]Missionare[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Missionare können in [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]Ureinwohnerdörfern[\LINK] christliche [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Missionen[COLOR_REVERT] errichten, die dort automatisch [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]Konvertierte Ureinwohner[\LINK] entstehen lassen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Die Errichtung der ersten Mission erfolgt stets problemlos. Später sinkt mit jeder neuen Mission, die man bei der selben Ureinwohnernation errichtet, die Wahrscheinlichkeit, dass die Errichtung der nächsten Mission gelingt. Scheitert die Errichtung einer Mission, belastet dies die diplomatischen Beziehungen zu dieser Ureinwohnernation. Eine erfolgreiche Errichtung einer Mission verbessert diese jedoch auch.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Einen Missionar erhält man, indem man einem beliebigen Bürger den Beruf des Missionars zuweist. Dies ist im europäischen Heimathafen möglich oder in einer der eigenen Siedlungen.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Existiert in einem Indianerdorf bereits eine Mission einer anderen europäischen Partei, kann man sie mit einem eigenen Missionar verdrängen und sie in eine eigene Mission umwandeln. Die Konkurrenz kann das natürlich auch. Die Verdrängung einer existierende Mission hat negativen Einfluss auf die Beziehungen zu dessen Besitzer.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Der [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]Jesuitenmissionar[\LINK] und der [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY_PROT]Evangelist[\LINK] (die protestantische Variante) sind die Experteneinheiten für den Beruf des Missionars. Schickt man einen von ihnen als Missionar in ein Ureinwohnerdorf, kann er dort eine Mission errichten, die doppelt so schnell Konvertierte Ureinwohner hervorbringt als herkömmliche Missionen. Außerdem erhöht ihr Einsatz die Wahrscheinlichkeit, dass die Errichtung einer Mission gelingt. Diese Einheiten benötigen eine Universität zur Ausbildung.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Aufstacheln von Ureinwohnern[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Missionare haben die Fähigkeit Ureinwohnerdörfer gegen die Europäer aufzustacheln. Dies kann in einem Spiel jedoch nur einmal pro Stadt geschehen. Das Aufstacheln bring junge Krieger eines Dorfes dazu auf einen Raubzug zu gehen. Man sollte aber vorsichtig sein, da das Ziel dieses Raubzuges nicht beeinflusst werden kann und somit auch eigene Städte in Gefahr sind, wenn man Ureinwohnerdörfer in deren Nähe aufstachelt.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Klöster[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Man kann Missionare auch nutzen um ein Kloster zu bemannen. Klöster werden von [LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]Pionieren[\LINK] gebaut, benötigen aber einen Missionar darin, um aktiv zu werden. Für weitere Informationen siehe Spielkonzept [LINK=CONCEPT_MONASTERIES]Klöster[\LINK] .
TEXT.Italian: [H1]MISSIONARI[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I missionari sono speciali unità d'esplorazione che possono fondare "missioni" negli insediamenti dei [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]nativi[\LINK]. Col tempo le missioni creano [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]nativi convertiti[\LINK], che puoi impiegare nelle tue colonie come produttori esperti, e gratuiti, di materie prime oppure come mediocri fabbricanti di beni.[PARAGRAPH:2]Prima di poter creare una missione devi creare un missionario. Puoi assegnare un colono a questa [LINK=CONCEPT_PROFESSIONS]professione[\LINK] dalla schermata dell'insediamento: [clicca due volte] sul colono a cui vuoi dare l'incarico e seleziona il missionario dalla lista delle professioni disponibili, oppure muovendo un'unità nella stessa casella di un insediamento nella schermata di gioco principale e selezionando l'ordine "Cambia professione". [PARAGRAPH:2]Dopo aver assegnato un colono alla professione di missionario, questi verrà inviato fuori dalla colonia. A questo punto potrai mandarlo in un insediamento di [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]nativi[\LINK] e selezionare il pulsante "Fonda missione", sacrificandolo. Compiendo questa azione con un [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]missionario gesuita[\LINK] aumenterai notevolmente il ritmo di creazione di [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]nativi convertiti[\LINK].[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Stirring Up Natives[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Missionaries are able to stir up Natives in a village. This can happen only one time per village. Stirring up Natives will cause some young Natives to go onto a raid against the evil White Man. But be careful, they might also choose your own colonies as target, if you do not pay attention where you stir up.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]MISIONEROS[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Los Misioneros son unidades especiales de exploración que fundan "misiones" en los asentamientos de los [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]Nativos[\LINK]. Con el tiempo, las misiones crearán [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]Nativos conversos[\LINK], a los que puedes emplear como productores expertos ?y gratuitos? de materias primas o productores mediocres de mercancías manufacturadas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Para poder fundar una misión debes haber creado antes a un Misionero. Puedes asignar esta [LINK=CONCEPT_PROFESSIONS]profesión[\LINK] a un Colono desde la pantalla del asentamiento haciendo [double-clicking] en el Colono que quieras asignar y seleccionando "Misionero" en la lista de profesiones disponibles. También puedes llevar una unidad a la casilla de uno de tus asentamientos, en la pantalla principal del juego, y seleccionar la orden "Cambiar de profesión". [PARAGRAPH:2]Tras asignarle a un Colono la profesión de Misionero, enviarás a éste fuera de la colonia. Desde allí, puedes llevarlo a un asentamiento de los [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]Nativos[\LINK] y pulsar el botón "Fundar misión", lo cual consumirá al Misionero. Si lo haces con un [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]Misionero jesuita[\LINK], se aumentará la velocidad a la que se creen los [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]Nativos conversos[\LINK].[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Stirring Up Natives[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Missionaries are able to stir up Natives in a village. This can happen only one time per village. Stirring up Natives will cause some young Natives to go onto a raid against the evil White Man. But be careful, they might also choose your own colonies as target, if you do not pay attention where you stir up.

TEXT.English: Native Trading Posts
TEXT.German: Handelsposten in Ureinwohnerdörfern

TEXT.English: [H1]Native Trading Posts[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Traders[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][LINK=PROFESSION_NATIVE_TRADER]Native traders[\LINK] are special [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]units[\LINK] who put [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]trading posts[COLOR_REVERT] in [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]Native[\LINK] [LINK=CONCEPT_SETTLEMENTS]settlements[\LINK]. Over time trading posts accumulate money into [LINK=UNIT_TREASURE]treasures[\LINK] to be sent back to the colonies.[PARAGRAPH:1]Before you can create a trading post, you must first have a Native trader. First of all, your trader needs 100 trade goods to get the business started. Once that's in your warehouse you can assign a colonist to this [LINK=CONCEPT_PROFESSIONS]profession[\LINK] from the settlement screen by double-clicking the colonist and selecting [LINK=PROFESSION_NATIVE_TRADER]Native trader[\LINK] from the list of available professions, or by moving a unit onto the same tile as one of your settlements on the main game screen and selecting [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]"Change Profession"[COLOR_REVERT].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Trading Posts[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]After assigning a colonist to the Native trader profession, your Native trader will travel, venturing into a Native village to click the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]"Create Trading Post"[COLOR_REVERT] button, which will consume the Native trader. Doing this with an [LINK=UNIT_EXPERT_TRADER]Expert Native Trader[\LINK] greatly increases the rate at which new [LINK=UNIT_TREASURE]treasures[\LINK] are created. Native villages with larger populations shopping at the trading posts accelerate the gold collected and thus the regularity with which new [LINK=UNIT_TREASURE]treasures[\LINK] trundle out of the villages toward your ports.
TEXT.German: [H1]Ureinwohnerhandelsposten[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ureinwohnerhändler[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][LINK=PROFESSION_NATIVE_TRADER]Ureinwohnerhändler[\LINK] sind spezielle [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Einheiten[\LINK], die [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Handelsposten[COLOR_REVERT] in [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]Ureinwohnerdörfern[\LINK] errichten können. Mit der Zeit erzeugen Handelsposten Gold, welches sie dann als [LINK=UNIT_TREASURE]Schätze[\LINK] zurück in die Kolonien schicken.[PARAGRAPH:2]Bevor man einen Handelsposten errichten kann, benötigt man zuerst einen Ureinwohnerhändler. Man kann einen Kolonisten diesen [LINK=CONCEPT_PROFESSIONS]Beruf[\LINK] entweder im Stadtbildschirm, oder durch [double-clicking] auf den Kolonisten und Auswahl [LINK=PROFESSION_NATIVE_TRADER]Ureinwohnerhändler[\LINK] aus der Liste der Berufe zuweisen. Ebenfalls möglich ist es auf der Karteansicht, wenn der Kolonist auf einer Stadt steht, den Button [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]"Beruf ändern"[COLOR_REVERT] zu verwenden.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Handelsposten[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Nachdem der Kolonist diesem Beruf zugewiesen ist, wird der Ureinwohnerhänlder aus der Kolonie geschickt. Von hier aus wander er zu einem Ureinwohnerdorf, wo man den Button [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]"Handelsposten gründen"[COLOR_REVERT] benutzen kann, welches dann auch den Ureinwohnerhändler verbraucht. Nutzt man einen [LINK=UNIT_EXPERT_TRADER]Erfahrenen Ureinwohnerhändler[\LINK] erhöht dies drastisch die Rate mit der [LINK=UNIT_TREASURE]Schätze[\LINK] erzeugt werden. Eine größere Bevölkerung in den Ureinwohnerdörfern mit Handelsposten erhöht ebenfalls die erwirtschaftete Goldmenge und somit die Frequenz mit der [LINK=UNIT_TREASURE]Schätze[\LINK] erzeugt werden.

TEXT.French: Monastères
TEXT.German: Klöster
TEXT.Italian: Monasteries
TEXT.Spanish: Monasteries

TEXT.English: [H1]MONASTERIES[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Constructing Monasteries[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Monasteries[COLOR_REVERT] are improvements that can be built by [LINK=UNIT_PIONEER]pioneers[\LINK]. They serve multiple functions, most of which have to do with [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]Natives[\LINK]. There are two types of monasteries: the regular [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MONASTERY]monastery[\LINK], which can be constructed by pioneers, and the [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LARGE_MONASTERY]large monastery[\LINK], the automatic upgrade once the monastery is well-established.[PARAGRAPH:1]Monasteries can be built on any land plot except for peaks, unless that tile lies inside the [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]borders[\LINK] of another Native or European nation.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Working Monasteries[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]To [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]work[COLOR_REVERT] a monastery, assign a colonist to the [LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]missionary[\LINK] profession (which can done in Europe or in one of your settlements), and then move that missionary to the monastery and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]fortify[COLOR_REVERT] him on that plot. [PARAGRAPH:1]Once a monastery is being worked, you can hover your mouse over it to see how many turns it will take to upgrade to a large monastery.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Effects of Monasteries[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]There are several [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]effects[COLOR_REVERT] that monasteries can have when Indigenous people pass by. The Natives may bring small amounts of gold to the monastery as [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]gifts[COLOR_REVERT], they can join your settlement as [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]converted Natives[\LINK], and braves planning to raid nearby [LINK=CONCEPT_SETTLEMENTS]towns[\LINK] might be [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]appeased[COLOR_REVERT], returning to their villages.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Increasing Effectiveness[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]The chances for positive events to happen will be doubled when [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]Jesuit missionaries[\LINK] or [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY_PROT]evangelists[\LINK] are employed. Success is also quite dependent on how many Natives walk by, so try to build monasteries where there's a lot of pedestrian traffic.[PARAGRAPH:1]Putting extra missionaries in a single monastery provides no additional bonus.
TEXT.French: [H1]MONASTÈRES[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Construire des monastères[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Les [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Monastères[COLOR_REVERT] sont des améliorations qui peuvent être construites par des [LINK=UNIT_PIONEER]pionniers[\LINK] pour remplir de nombreuses fonctions, en particulier vis-à-vis des [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]indigènes[\LINK]. Il y a deux types de monastères : les [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MONASTERY]Monastères[\LINK] normaux, qui peuvent être construit par les pionniers, et les [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LARGE_MONASTERY]grands monastères[\LINK], qui sont une amélioration remplaçant les monastères normaux au bout d'une certaine période d'activité.[NEWLINE]Les monastères peuvent être construits sur n'importe quel type de terrain à l'esception des montagnes, à moins que la case soit inclue à l'intérieur des [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]frontières[\LINK] d'une civilisation indigène ou d'une autre nation européenne.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Travailler dans un monastère[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Pour [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]travailler[COLOR_REVERT] dans un monastère, assignez à un colon la profession de [LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]Missionaire[\LINK], puis placer le missionnaire sur la case du monastère en lui donnant l'ordre de se [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]fortifier[COLOR_REVERT]. [NEWLINE]Une fois qu'un missionnaire travaille, vous pouvez survoler votre souris sur lui pour voir le nombre de tours nécessaires pour que le monastère soit amélioré en grand monastère.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Effets des monastères[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Lorsque les indigènes s'aventurent dans une case où est présente un monastère, le brave peut faire un petit [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]on en or[COLOR_REVERT], il peut également être [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]converti[COLOR_REVERT] et rejoindre votre nation en temps qu'[LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]indigène converti[\LINK], et les braves qui auraient l'intention de faire un raid sur une [LINK=CONCEPT_SETTLEMENTS]colonie[\LINK] avoisinante pourraient être convaincu de retourner dans leur village.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Augmenter l'efficacité[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Les chances que l'un des événements positifs précités arrivent doublent lorsque les [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]missionnaires jésuites[\LINK] ou les [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY_PROT]évangélistes[\LINK] sont employés. Son succès est également dépendant du nombre d'indigènes qui rôdent, donc il faut penser à les construire là où ils se déplacent fréquemement.[NEWLINE]Assigner plusieurs missionnaires sur le même monastère n'apporte aucun bonus additionnel.
TEXT.German: [H1]Klöster[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Bau von Klöstern[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Klöster[COLOR_REVERT] sind Geländefeldverbesserungen, die von [LINK=UNIT_PIONEER]Pionieren[\LINK] erbaut werden und eine Vielzahl von Funktionen erfüllen, die meist in Zusammenhang mit den [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]Ureinwohnern[\LINK] stehen. Das normale [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_MONASTERY]Kloster[\LINK] kann über die Zeit zu einem [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_LARGE_MONASTERY]Grossen Kloster[\LINK] heranwachsen, wenn es in Betrieb gehalten wird.[NEWLINE]Klöster können nur ausserhalb der [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Grenzen[\LINK] anderer Nationen erbaut werden, seien es Ureinwohner oder andere Kolonialmächte.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Nutzung von Klöstern[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Um ein Kloster zu bemannen, muss eine Einheit im Beruf [LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]Missionar[\LINK] darin [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]befestigt[COLOR_REVERT] werden.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Effekte eines Klosters[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Es gibt eine Vielzahl von Effekten von Klöstern, die meist dann ausgelöst werden, wenn ein Ureinwohner dieses passiert oder betritt. Dies kann sich in [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Geschenken[COLOR_REVERT] aber auch [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Konvertierung[COLOR_REVERT] des Ureinwohners auswirken, wodurch dieser dann zu einem [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]Konvertierten Ureinwohner[\LINK] wird. Auch kann ein Kloster wütende Ureinwohner auf dem Weg zu einem [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ueberfall[COLOR_REVERT] auf eine nahegelegen [LINK=CONCEPT_SETTLEMENTS]Siedlung[\LINK] besänftigen, wodurch dieser dann wieder seine übliche Wanderschaft aufnimmt.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Erhöhung der Effektivität[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Die Wahrscheinlichkeit der genannten Effekte lässt sich erhöhen, indem die Spezialisten [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY]Jesuitenmissionar[\LINK] oder [LINK=UNIT_CHRISTIAN_MISSIONARY_PROT]Evangelist[\LINK] in den Klöstern eingesetzt werden. Des weiteren hängt der Erfolg natürlich auch von der Lage ab, sprich wie viele Ureinwohner den Standort des Klosters passieren.[NEWLINE]Der Einsatz von mehreren Missionaren gleichzeitig in einer Mission führt nicht zu einer Steigerung der Effektivität.

TEXT.English: Movement
TEXT.German: Fortbewegung

TEXT.English: [H1]MOVEMENT[\H1][NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]In "We The People", a significant portion of your time is spent moving your [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]units[\LINK] around on the map: you send them out to [LINK=CONCEPT_VISIBILITY]explore[\LINK] new territory; you send them into [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]battle[\LINK]; and so forth. The basic rules of movement are simple: each unit in the game has [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]"movement points"[COLOR_REVERT] (MPs) which they can expend each turn.[PARAGRAPH:1]Units spend MPs entering a new square. Some [LINK=CONCEPT_NEW_WORLD]terrain[\LINK] is more difficult to move through (and thus costs more MPs to enter), some less so, and some terrain is even [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]impassable[COLOR_REVERT] to some or all units.[PARAGRAPH:1]Certain [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]improvements[\LINK] make it easier to enter certain tiles, [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]roads[COLOR_REVERT] in particular.[PARAGRAPH:1]There are two basic unit types in the game: land units and [LINK=CONCEPT_SHIPS]sea units[\LINK].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Land Movement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Land units[COLOR_REVERT] can move only on land terrain. They may not move onto water (unless [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]carried[\LINK] aboard a sea transport unit). [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Water Movement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Water units[COLOR_REVERT] travel on [LINK=TERRAIN_OCEAN]ocean[\LINK], [LINK=TERRAIN_COAST]coastal[\LINK], and [LINK=CONCEPT_SETTLEMENTS]port[\LINK] squares. Small boats can travel up large rivers. They cannot move onto land spaces.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Movement Speed[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Generally [LINK=CONCEPT_MILITARY_UNITS]foot soldiers[\LINK], non-military units and siege units have 1 MP, while [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]mounted units[COLOR_REVERT] have 2 MPs or more. [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Land transport units[COLOR_REVERT] have anywhere from 1 to 3 MPs. See [LINK=CONCEPT_MILITARY_UNITS]Military Units[\LINK] and [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]Transport[\LINK] for details.[PARAGRAPH:1]Water units can have a movement speed between 3 and 6, but certain promotions such as [LINK=PROMOTION_NAVIGATION1]Navigation I[\LINK] can increase a ship's movement points.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Terrain Cost[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Open terrain - land without any features such as [LINK=FEATURE_FOREST]forest[\LINK] - cost 1 MP to enter. Hills, peaks, taiga, light forest, jungles, and forests cost 2 MPs. Plots that contain both hills and another feature, such as jungle, cost 3 MPs.[NEWLINE]This penalty can be negated if units gain certain [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]promotions[\LINK]. Mounted units can get the [LINK=PROMOTION_EXPLORER1]Explorer I[\LINK] promotion, making them faster by one over all plots with a natural movement cost of two or more. For melee and gunpowder units, there are certain specialized promotions, such as [LINK=PROMOTION_MOUNTAINEER1]Mountaineer II[\LINK], that not only remove all movement penalties for a plot with a certain terrain feature, but also double the unit's movement across such tiles.[PARAGRAPH:1]For most ocean tiles, the movement cost is one. However, your ships can get movement bonuses or penalties in certain weather systems. For an overview of these, see [LINK=CONCEPT_WINDS_AND_STORMS]Winds and Storms[\LINK][PARAGRAPH:2]Note: A unit can [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]always[COLOR_REVERT] enter a space if it has any MPs left. Thus, a 1 MP unit could enter a forest space, but its movement points would be spent at that point.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Roads[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Roads[COLOR_REVERT] reduce the movement costs of terrain; all spaces cost 1/2 MP to enter. This benefit occurs only when a unit is moving from [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]one road square to another[COLOR_REVERT], and only when the square the unit is entering is not within the [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]borders[\LINK] of a nation with whom that unit's leader is at [LINK=CONCEPT_WAR]war[\LINK].[PARAGRAPH:1]There are NO road bonuses when crossing rivers! This means that if a unit moves along a road and then crosses a river tile, it will consume as many MP as if there were no road there.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Effects of Borders on Movement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Your units can move freely within your [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]territory[\LINK] and unclaimed territory, as well as through territory of civilizations with whom you have an [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Open Borders[\LINK] treaty, or borders of [LINK=CONCEPT_NATIVES]Native[\LINK] nations with whom you are not at war.[PARAGRAPH:1]If you enter the territory of a non-native civilization without such a treaty, you declare [LINK=CONCEPT_WAR]war[\LINK] on them. You do not get the benefits of roads when moving through [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]enemy territory[COLOR_REVERT], which gives your enemy a huge logistical advantage inside his own borders.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Effects of Other Units on Movement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Other [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]friendly or neutral units[\LINK] do not affect your units' movement at all; in other words, your units can move onto the same space as a foreign unit without attacking it. However, if your unit enters a space containing an enemy unit, that will initiate [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]combat[\LINK] with the enemy, unless your unit is a non-military unit, such as a [LINK=PROFESSION_COLONIST]colonist[\LINK] or an [LINK=UNIT_OXCART]oxcart[\LINK].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Entering Peaks[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Peaks[COLOR_REVERT] are impassible to most units. Only certain [LINK=CONCEPT_PROFESSION]professions[\LINK] or units may enter peaks without roads. These are [LINK=UNIT_RANGER]rangers[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_NATIVE]Natives[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_NATIVE_MERC]Native mercenaries[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]seasoned scouts[\LINK], units with the [LINK=PROMOTION_MOUNTAINEER1]Mountaineer I[\LINK] promotion or colonists with the [LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]pioneer[\LINK] profession as well as some units with a profession related to mountains and hills like stonecutters, miners and prospectors.[PARAGRAPH:1]Once [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]roads[COLOR_REVERT] are built on a peak tile, all units can cross it.
TEXT.French: [H1]DÉPLACEMENT[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Dans Colonization, vous passerez une grande partie de votre temps à déplacer vos [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]unités[\LINK] aux quatre coins de la carte : vous les envoyez [LINK=CONCEPT_VISIBILITY]explorer[\LINK], combattre, etc. Les principes de base du déplacement sont simples : chaque unité du jeu possède un certain nombre de points de mouvement (PM) disponibles à chaque tour. Les unités utilisent des PM dès qu'elles entrent dans une nouvelle case. Certains terrains sont plus difficilement praticables (les traverser requiert donc davantage de PM), d'autres un peu moins, d'autres encore sont infranchissables. Certains [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]aménagements[\LINK] permettent de réduire le coût en PM de la traversée de certaines cases de terrain.[PARAGRAPH:2]Le jeu comprend deux types d'unités de base : les unités terrestres et les unités navales.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Déplacement terrestre[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Le seul type de [LINK=CONCEPT_NEW_WORLD]terrain[\LINK] praticable par les unités terrestres est la terre ferme. Elles sont incapables de se déplacer sur l'eau (à moins d'être [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]transportées[\LINK] par une unité de transport naval). Sachez également que les unités terrestres ne peuvent pénétrer les cases de [LINK=TERRAIN_PEAK]pitons rocheux[\LINK]. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vitesse de déplacement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]En règle générale, les fantassins disposent d'un PM alors que les unités montées en possèdent 2. Pour plus de détails, veuillez consulter l'article consacré aux [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]unités[\LINK]. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Coût des terrains[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Terrain ouvert, soit prairie, plaine, désert, toundra et glace : 1 PM. Collines, jungle et forêt : 2 PM.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note : quel que soit le nombre de PM qu'il lui reste, une unité peut entrer dans une case. Ainsi, une unité ne possédant qu'un PM peut entrer dans une forêt, mais son mouvement s'arrêtera là (pour plus de détails, veuillez consulter l'article consacré au [LINK=CONCEPT_NEW_WORLD](Nouveau) Monde[\LINK]). [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Routes[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Les routes réduisent le coût de déplacement des différents types de terrains : la traversée de tout type de terrain coûte la moitié des PM habituellement requis. Cet avantage survient lorsqu'une unité se déplace d'une case avec route vers une case similaire, et uniquement lorsque la case sur laquelle se rend l'unité ne se situe pas à l'intérieur des [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]frontières[\LINK] d'une civilisation hostile. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Rivières[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Traverser les rivières annule l'effet des routes. Ainsi, une unité se déplaçant le long d'une route qui coupe une case de rivière, dépensera autant de PM pour la traverser que s'il n'y avait pas de route. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Déplacement maritime[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Les unités navales ne peuvent se déplacer que sur des cases d'océan, de côtes et de colonies côtières. Elles sont incapables de se déplacer sur la terre ferme. Les unités maritimes ne peuvent pas non plus se rendre sur les cases de glace. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vitesse de déplacement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Les PM des unités navales oscillent entre 3 et 4. Avec les améliorations adéquates, ce total peut aller jusqu'à 6 PM. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Coût des terrains[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Océan et côtes : 1 PM. Les cases de glace sont infranchissables. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Promotions[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Certaines [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]promotions[\LINK] permettent aux unités de se déplacer plus rapidement lorsqu'elles traversent un certain type de terrain, ou leur octroient simplement davantage de PM. Par exemple, la promotion [LINK=PROMOTION_NAVIGATION1]Navigation[\LINK] octroie davantage de PM aux unités navales. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Effets des frontières sur le déplacement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Vos unités peuvent se déplacer librement sur votre territoire et en zone neutre, ainsi que sur les territoires des civilisations avec lesquelles vous avez signé un accord de LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]libre passage[\LINK]. Si vous pénétrez sur le territoire d'une civilisation non-indigène sans un tel accord, vous lui déclarerez automatiquement la [LINK=CONCEPT_WAR]guerre[\LINK]. En territoire ennemi, vous ne bénéficiez pas des avantages de déplacement octroyés par les routes. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Effets des autres unités sur le déplacement[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Les unités alliées ou neutres n'affectent en rien votre déplacement. En d'autres termes, vos unités peuvent les rencontrer sans les attaquer. En revanche, si vos unités se rendent sur une case occupée par une unité ennemie, elles engageront immédiatement le [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]combat[\LINK].[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Gravir des Pics[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Seules certaines professions ou unités peuvent franchir des montagnes en toutes circonstances, avec ou sans route. Il s'agit des Rangers, des indigènes, des mercenaires indigènes, les éclaireurs aguerris ou les pionniers (profession). Les autres unités ne peuvent franchir une montagne que si une route est construite. Une fois la route construite, toutes les unités peuvent franchir les montagnes.
TEXT.German: [H1]Fortbewegung[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In Colonization verbringen Sie viel Zeit damit, Ihre [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Einheiten[\LINK] auf der Karte zu bewegen - Sie entsenden Einheiten, um die noch unerforschten Gebiete der Karte zu [LINK=CONCEPT_VISIBILITY]erkunden[\LINK]; Sie lassen sie in den Krieg ziehen usw. Die Grundregeln für die Fortbewegung sind denkbar einfach: Jede Einheit des Spiels hat pro Runde eine vorgegebene Zahl von Fortbewegungspunkten (FP). Betritt eine Einheit ein neues Geländefeld verbraucht sie einen FP. Einige Geländearten sind vergleichsweise unwegsam (und kosten daher mehr FP) oder unpassierbar. Bestimmte [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]Modernisierungen[\LINK] senken die Fortbewegungskosten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die Einheiten des Spiels lassen sich in zwei Grundtypen einteilen: Landeinheiten und Marineeinheiten.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Bewegung an Land[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Landeinheiten können sich nur auf Land-[LINK=CONCEPT_NEW_WORLD]Geländefeldern[\LINK] bewegen. Auf Wasser-Geländefeldern können sie sich nicht bewegen (es sei denn, sie werden von einer Wasser-Transporteinheit [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]befördert[\LINK]).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Fortbewegungsgeschwindigkeit[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Zumeist haben Fußsoldaten einen, Kavallerie und Transportwagen zwei oder mehr FP. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie im Abschnitt [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Einheiten[\LINK]. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Fortbewegungskosten[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Die Fortbewegung auf offenem Gelände (Savanne, Prärie, Wüste, Tundra und Eis) kostet 1 FP. Betreten Sie Hügel, Gipfel, Dschungel und Wälder, werden 2 FP fällig.[PARAGRAPH:2]Hinweis: Solange eine Einheit Fortbewegungspunkte hat, kann sie sich fortbewegen. Sie darf mit 1 FP also ein Wald-Geländefeld betreten, kann von dort aber nicht weiter vorrücken. (Im Abschnitt [LINK=CONCEPT_NEW_WORLD]Neue Welt[\LINK] finden Sie weitere Informationen dazu.) [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Straßen[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Straßen senken die Fortbewegungskosten auf allen Geländefeldern der Straße auf 1/2 FP pro Geländefeld. Dieser Bonus gilt nur, wenn sich eine Einheit von einem Straßen-Geländefeld auf ein anderes bewegt, und gilt NICHT für Geländefelder innerhalb der [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Grenzen[\LINK] einer feindlichen Zivilisation.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Flüsse[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Bei der Überquerung von Flüssen gelten KEINE Straßenboni! Das bedeutet, dass eine Einheit, die sich auf einer Straße entlang bewegt und dann ein Fluss-Geländefeld überquert, so viele FP verbraucht, als wäre dort keine Straße. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Bewegung im Wasser[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Marineeinheiten können ausschließlich Ozean-, Küsten- und Siedlungs-Geländefelder befahren. Land können sie, genau wie Eis, nicht betreten.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Fortbewegungsgeschwindigkeit[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Marineeinheiten haben 3 oder 4 FP. Durch entsprechende Modernisierungen erhöht sich diese Zahl auf maximal 6 FP. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Fortbewegungskosten[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Küsten- und Ozean-Geländefelder kosten 1 FP. Eis-Geländefelder sind unpassierbar.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Beförderungen[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Bestimmte [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]Beförderungen[\LINK] erhöhen die Fortbewegungsgeschwindigkeit Ihrer Einheiten auf bestimmten Geländearten oder erhöhen die Zahl der Fortbewegungspunkte einer Einheit. So erhalten beispielsweise Marineeinheiten mit [LINK=PROMOTION_NAVIGATION1]Navigations[\LINK]beförderungen zusätzliche FP. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Grenzen und Fortbewegung[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ihre Einheiten können sich innerhalb Ihrer Grenzen und auf neutralem Boden frei bewegen. Dies gilt auch für das Hoheitsgebiet von Kolonialmächten, mit denen Sie ein [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]Offene-Grenzen[\LINK]-Abkommen geschlossen haben. Ist dies nicht der Fall, gilt jede Grenzüberschreitung als kriegerischer Akt. Darüber hinaus kommen Ihre Einheiten nicht in den Genuss der Fortbewegungsboni der Straßen und Schienenwege der jeweiligen Zivilisation. Ausgenommen sind Planwagen und Trecks, die sich überall frei bewegen können.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Auswirkung anderer Einheiten auf die Fortbewegung[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Die Fortbewegung Ihrer Einheiten wird durch andere verbündete oder neutrale Einheiten nicht beeinträchtigt. Betritt Ihre Einheit allerdings das Geländefeld einer feindlichen Einheit, kommt es automatisch zum [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]Kampf[\LINK].[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Betreten von Bergen[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Nur bestimmte Berufe oder Einheiten können Berge ohne Strassen betreten. Dies sind beispielsweise Ranger, Ureinwohner, Indianische Söldner, Erfahrene Kundschafter, Prospektoren, Minen- und Bergarbeiter oder Kolonisten im Beruf des Pioniers. Sobald eine Strasse gebaut wurde, können Berge wieder von allen Landeinheiten betreten werden.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]MOVIMENTO[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In Colonization passerai molto tempo a muovere le tue [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]unità[\LINK] all'interno della mappa di gioco: le puoi mandare ad [LINK=CONCEPT_VISIBILITY]esplorare[\LINK] nuovi territori, farle marciare in battaglia, e così via. Le regole principali del movimento sono molto semplici: ogni unità all'interno del gioco dispone di un certo numero di "punti movimento" (PM) che può utilizzare nel corso di ogni turno. Le unità spendono PM quando entrano in una nuova casella. Alcune tipologie di terreno sono più difficili da attraversare, e di conseguenza richiedono più PM per entrarci; altri terreni costano meno, altri ancora sono impraticabili. Sono disponibili alcuni [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]miglioramenti[\LINK] che riducono il costo di ingresso in determinati tipi di terreno.[PARAGRAPH:2]Esistono due tipologie principali di unità nel gioco: di terra e navali.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Movimento a terra[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Le unità di terra possono muoversi solo su [LINK=CONCEPT_NEW_WORLD]caselle di terra[\LINK]. Non possono muoversi sull'acqua (a meno di non essere [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]trasportate[\LINK] a bordo di un'unità di trasporto navale). [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Velocità di movimento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Solitamente, i soldati a piedi hanno 1 PM, mentre le unità montate hanno 2 PM o più. Vedi la sezione[LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]unità[\LINK] per altri dettagli. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Costo per il movimento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Terreno aperto - praterie, pianure, deserto, tundra e ghiaccio richiedono 1 PM per entrare. Colline, montagne, giungla e foreste costano invece 2 PM.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nota: un'unità può sempre entrare in una casella se le avanzano dei PM; ad esempio, un'unità con 1 PM potrebbe comunque entrare in una casella di foresta, ma il movimento si interromperebbe in quel punto (vedi [LINK=CONCEPT_NEW_WORLD]Nuovo Mondo[\LINK] per ulteriori dettagli). [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Strade[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Le strade riducono il costo di movimento del terreno su cui sono costruite; entrare in qualsiasi casella contenente strade costa 1/2 PM. Questo beneficio si ottiene solo quando un'unità si muove da una casella di strada all'altra, e solo quando la casella in cui sta entrando l'unità non si trova all'interno di [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]confini[\LINK] nemici. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Fiumi[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]L'attraversamento dei fiumi annulla gli effetti delle strade, quindi un'unità che si sposta su una strada e che deve attraversare un fiume userà i punti movimento come se la strada non esistesse. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Movimento in acqua[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Le unità navali possono entrare solo nelle caselle di oceano, di costa e degli insediamenti costieri. Non possono muoversi su caselle di terra, e neppure in quelle di ghiaccio. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Velocità di movimento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Le unità navali hanno tra 3 e 4 PM. Con le giuste promozioni possono salire fino a 6 PM. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Costo per il movimento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Tutte le caselle di costa e di oceano costano 1 PM per entrare; gli spazi di ghiaccio sono impenetrabili. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Promozioni[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Alcune [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]promozioni[\LINK] consentono alle unità di muoversi più rapidamente all'interno di certi tipi di terreno, oppure assegnano punti movimento extra tutti in una volta. Ad esempio, le promozioni [LINK=PROMOTION_NAVIGATION1]navigazione[\LINK] assegnano punti movimento aggiuntivi alle unità navali. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Effetti dei confini sul movimento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Le tue unità possono muoversi liberamente all'interno del tuo territorio e in quello non reclamato da nessuno, così come in quello delle civiltà con cui hai un trattato per il [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]diritto di passaggio[\LINK]. Entrare nel territorio di una civiltà non nativa con cui non hai questo tipo di accordo equivale a dichiararle [LINK=CONCEPT_WAR]guerra[\LINK]. Quando ti muovi in territorio nemico non hai i benefici del movimento su caselle con strade. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Effetti delle altre unità sul movimento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Unità alleate o neutrali non hanno alcuna influenza sul movimento delle tue unità; in altre parole, ti puoi muovere liberamente nelle caselle occupate da un'unità straniera senza attaccarla. Se invece una tua unità entra in una casella contenente un'unità nemica (ossia di una civiltà con cui sei in guerra), la tua unità inizierà a [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]combattere[\LINK].[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Entering Peaks[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Only certain profession or units may enter peaks without roads. These are Rangers, Natives, Native Mercenaries, Experienced Scouts or Colonists with profession Pioneer. Once roads are built, all units can enter the peaks.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]MOVIMIENTO[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]En Colonization, una gran parte del tiempo se dedica a mover las [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]unidades[\LINK] por el mapa. Éstas se envían a [LINK=CONCEPT_VISIBILITY]explorar[\LINK] nuevos territorios, a marchar hacia la batalla y demás. Las reglas básicas del movimiento son sencillas: cada unidad del juego tiene una cierta cantidad de "puntos de movimiento" (PM) que puede gastar en cada turno. Las unidades gastan PM al entrar en una nueva casilla. Ciertos terrenos son más difíciles de atravesar que otros (entrar en ellos cuesta, por tanto, más PM), y algunos son incluso infranqueables. Ciertas [LINK=CONCEPT_IMPROVEMENTS]mejoras[\LINK] reducen el coste de entrar en casillas determinadas.[PARAGRAPH:2]En el juego hay dos tipos básicos de unidades: las terrestres y las marítimas.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Movimiento por tierra[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Las unidades terrestres solo pueden moverse por [LINK=CONCEPT_NEW_WORLD]terreno[\LINK] que esté en tierra firme. No pueden entrar en el agua (a menos que se [LINK=CONCEPT_TRANSPORT]transporten[\LINK] a bordo de una unidad marítima con esa capacidad). [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Velocidad de movimiento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Por lo general, los soldados de infantería tienen 1 PM, mientras que las unidades montadas tienen 2 o más. Ver [LINK=CONCEPT_UNITS]Unidades[\LINK] para obtener más detalles. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Coste por terreno[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Cuesta 1 PM entrar en terreno abierto (pradera, llanura, desierto, hielo y tundra). La colina, los picos, la selva y el bosque cuestan 2 PM.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nota: Una unidad siempre puede entrar en una casilla si le queda algún PM. Así, una unidad con 1 PM puede entrar en una casilla de bosque, pero su movimiento terminará allí (consulta [LINK=CONCEPT_NEW_WORLD]El Nuevo Mundo[\LINK] para obtener más detalles). [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Carreteras[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Las carreteras reducen los costes de movimiento por terreno: entrar en cualquier casilla solo cuesta 1/2 PM. Este beneficio solo se da cuando una unidad pasa de una casilla con carretera a otra igual, y únicamente cuando la unidad entre en una casilla que no se encuentre en las [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]fronteras[\LINK] de una civilización hostil. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ríos[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Cruzar ríos elimina los efectos de las carreteras por lo que, si una unidad que se mueve por una carretera tiene que cruzar una casilla de río, gastará sus puntos de movimiento como si la carretera no estuviera presente. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Movimiento por agua[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Las unidades acuáticas solo pueden entrar en las casillas de océano, de costa y en las de los asentamientos costeros. No pueden entrar en casillas terrestres ni de hielo. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Velocidad de movimiento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Las unidades acuáticas tienen entre 3 y 4 PM. Con las modernizaciones apropiadas, pueden aumentar hasta 6. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Costes por terreno[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Entrar en todas las casillas de costa/océano cuesta 1 PM. Las casillas de hielo son infranqueables. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ascensos[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Ciertos [LINK=CONCEPT_PROMOTIONS]ascensos[\LINK] permiten a las unidades moverse más rápido por determinados tipos de terreno o les otorgan PM. Por ejemplo, los ascensos de [LINK=PROMOTION_NAVIGATION1]Navegación[\LINK] dan más puntos de movimiento a las unidades acuáticas. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Efectos de las fronteras en el movimiento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Tus unidades pueden moverse libremente por tu territorio y por aquél que no tenga dueño, así como por el territorio de otras civilizaciones con las que tengas un tratado de [LINK=CONCEPT_DIPLOMACY]apertura de fronteras[\LINK]. Si entras en el territorio de una civilización que no sea nativa sin tener con ella dicho tratado, le estarás declarando la [LINK=CONCEPT_WAR]guerra[\LINK]. Al moverse por territorio enemigo no se obtienen los beneficios que dan las carreteras. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Efectos de otras unidades en el movimiento[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Las demás unidades que sean amigas o neutrales no afectarán para nada al movimiento de las tuyas. En otras palabras, tus unidades podrán entrar en la casilla de una unidad extranjera sin atacarla. No obstante, cuando una unidad entre en una casilla en la que haya una unidad enemiga, iniciará un [LINK=CONCEPT_COMBAT]combate[\LINK] con ella.[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE][BOLD]Entering Peaks[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Only certain profession or units may enter peaks without roads. These are Rangers, Natives, Native Mercenaries, Experienced Scouts or Colonists with profession Pioneer. Once roads are built, all units can enter the peaks.

TEXT.English: Natives
TEXT.German: Ureinwohner

TEXT.English: [H1]NATIVES[\H1][NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]At the start of the game the New World belongs to its [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Indigenous people[COLOR_REVERT]. Most of the New World has already been settled by them. If you want to stand out from the other colonists, you have to barter, negotiate and fight with the Native nations to establish your own territory.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Encountering Natives[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]There are [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]thirty[COLOR_REVERT] different Indigenous cultures in the New World for you to encounter. Each has its own traditions, personality and attitude toward strangers. For an overview of the other nations in the game, see the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Rival Colonies[COLOR_REVERT] section of the Colopedia.[PARAGRAPH:1]You begin the game automatically at peace with the natives. You can travel through their territory without consequence, since they ignore all [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]borders[\LINK]. This means that they travel freely through your territory as well. A wise colonial leader will make friends with the Natives early, because many Native villages will give your colony gifts as a sign of friendship.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Visiting Native Settlements[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]When one of your units enters a new Native [LINK=CONCEPT_SETTLEMENTS]settlement[\LINK], click the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]"Speak with Chief"[COLOR_REVERT] button on the bottom of your screen. If your unit is the first European unit ever to speak to that settlement's chief, he receives experience points and either maps showing the surrounding unexplored lands, a gift of gold, a [LINK=UNIT_TREASURE]treasure[\LINK] or, if the unit is a [LINK=PROFESSION_SCOUT]scout[\LINK] who has no speciality yet, he might instantly become a [LINK=UNIT_SCOUT]seasoned scout[\LINK]. Seasoned scouts are vital to your early contacts with Natives, getting much more gold from them.[PARAGRAPH:1]Once you've met the chief, you can see which [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]profession[COLOR_REVERT] that village can teach to colonists, as well its [LINK=CONCEPT_TRADE]preferred good[\LINK], something with a higher value in that settlement. You can see both these things on the Information Panel widget below the settlement on the Main Map.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Native Teaching[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]If you are on good terms with the Natives, you can march any [LINK=UNIT_COLONIST]free colonist[\LINK], [LINK=UNIT_INDENTURED_SERVANT]indentured servant[\LINK] or [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]converted Native[\LINK] into a Native village and have that unit be [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]trained[COLOR_REVERT] in that village's area of expertise. This means that a [LINK=UNIT_COLONIST]free colonist[\LINK] can become an [LINK=UNIT_FISHERMAN]expert fisherman[\LINK] or [LINK=UNIT_COTTON_PLANTER]expert cotton planter[\LINK] or [LINK=UNIT_MINER]expert miner[\LINK] and so on. Each village has only one area of expertise which never changes.[PARAGRAPH:1]Once a colonist has been accepted into a Native settlement to be trained, they vanish for a few turns, emerging as a trained expert.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Missions[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]You can also [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]convert[COLOR_REVERT] natives to your religion, and have them join your colonies. There are two ways to do this.[PARAGRAPH:1]The first is by establishing [LINK=CONCEPT_MISSIONARIES]missions[\LINK] in Native villages. By assigning a colonist to the [LINK=PROFESSION_MISSIONARY]missionary[\LINK] profession, which you can only do in one of your own settlements or on the docks in Europe, you can send your newly-created missionary into a Native settlement and create a [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]mission[COLOR_REVERT]. Over time, missions will generate [LINK=UNIT_CONVERTED_NATIVE]converted Natives[\LINK] willing to join your newly-formed colony. Converted Natives are exceptional producers of raw materials and horses (although they cannot take up military professions) so, if you want to boost any raw materials production, a mission is an excellent investment.[PARAGRAPH:1]The other way to convince Natives to join your colonies is by building [LINK=CONCEPT_MONASTERY]monasteries[\LINK]. These improvements can be built by [LINK=PROFESSION_PIONEER]pioneers[\LINK] on any plot that lies either within your borders or in wilderness unclaimed by any nation. Moving a missionary into the monastery and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]fortifying[COLOR_REVERT] him on that tile will make him work the monastery. As they are worked monasteries will occasionally convert Natives wandering by, and generate other small bonuses as well.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Trading with Natives[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Natives can be valuable [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]trading partners[COLOR_REVERT] in the New World. While they are adept in gathering all kinds of raw materials, they are especially good in hunting and trapping animals for [LINK=YIELD_FUR]fur[\LINK] and [LINK=YIELD_PREMIUM_FUR]premium fur[\LINK]. They mine valuable earth resources like [LINK=YIELD_SILVER]silver[\LINK], [LINK=YIELD_GOLD]gold[\LINK] and [LINK=YIELD_GEMS]gems[\LINK]. They will offer these products for low prices, after which you can sell them again in Europe for significantly higher prices.[PARAGRAPH:1]Natives are also very interested in buying goods they cannot make themselves. This includes manufactured goods like [LINK=YIELD_RUM]rum[\LINK] or [LINK=YIELD_LEATHER]leather[\LINK], but also [LINK=CONCEPT_CATTLE_OR_SHEEP_BREEDING]livestock[\LINK], especially [LINK=YIELD_HORSES]horses[\LINK], which they need to make [LINK=PROFESSION_MOUNTED_BRAVE]mounted braves[\LINK]. Once they have a specific kind of livestock, they will start breeding it.[PARAGRAPH:1]Above all else the Natives want [LINK=YIELD_MUSKETS]guns[\LINK]. They pay top prices for them, much higher than the price in Europe. Once they have guns, the Natives are able to equip [LINK=PROFESSION_ARMED_BRAVE]armed braves[\LINK] and [LINK=PROFESSION_ARMED_MOUNTED_BRAVE]armed mounted braves[\LINK], their strongest soldiers. Be careful to which Natives you sell your guns, or you may see them pointed at you![PARAGRAPH:1]You can also [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]bargain[COLOR_REVERT] with Natives to try to get better deals. However, don't push your luck too far, since this can ruin your relationship with them! Villages get angry if you insult them with too much bargaining, and will refuse to trade with you for a few turns.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Purchasing Land[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]When you build a new settlement near a native village, you will be given the option to [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]purchase[COLOR_REVERT] the land for your settlement from the natives or simply [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]steal[COLOR_REVERT] the land. If you buy the land, the gold is instantly removed from your treasury, and the Natives will renounce any claims they have on that territory. Stealing the land means you keep your gold but your relations with the Natives worsens for every tile you take.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Native Raids[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]If your relations with the Natives are less than stellar, they may occasionally [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]raid[COLOR_REVERT] your settlements or attack unprotected [LINK=UNIT_TREASURE]treasure[\LINK] units you own. While you can attack them right back, you will need to declare [LINK=CONCEPT_WAR]war[\LINK] on their whole nation first, while Native raids are spontaneous acts of aggression that do not require war to be declared.[PARAGRAPH:1]Raids can happen to your [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]towns[COLOR_REVERT] and to unprotected [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]treasures[COLOR_REVERT]. While the willingness to raid European colonies differs vastly among different native tribes, Native raids usually are a clear sign that your relations with a Native nation are dangerously low. An exception would be the case in which the Natives were incited to raid by [LINK=CONCEPT_MISSIONARIES]missionaries[\LINK] of rival colonial powers.[PARAGRAPH:1]If you defend your colonies properly, Native raids will usually be [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]unsuccessful[COLOR_REVERT] and, sometimes, the raiding party might even be captured and forced to work the land as [LINK=UNIT_NATIVE_SLAVE]Native slaves[\LINK]. But when a raid is completely or even partially [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]successful[COLOR_REVERT], it can inflict multiple kinds of damage, like goods being stolen, money vanishing from your treasury, buildings being destroyed or even colonists being killed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Wars with Natives[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]If your relations with a Native nation deteriorate badly enough, there may be [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]war[COLOR_REVERT]. Natives might declare war if you steal too much of their land at once, if a unit other than a seasoned scout explores [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_GOODY_HUT]burial grounds[\LINK] or [LINK=IMPROVEMENT_GOODY_HUT2]ancient ruins[\LINK] near their settlements, if a third nation bribes them to declare war on you, or if they simply feel strong enough to attack you. You can declare war on them as well, of course.[PARAGRAPH:1]By marching [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]troops[COLOR_REVERT] into a native village, you can attack that settlement and, once you've killed every [LINK=PROFESSION_BRAVE]brave[\LINK] unit defending that village, destroy and ransack it for gold. Usually a [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]treasure[COLOR_REVERT] unit will be generated which can be converted into money by [LINK=CONCEPT_CHANGES_TO_TREASURES]transporting the treasure to Europe[\LINK]. Sometimes part of the Native population will survive, and you will receive a [LINK=UNIT_NATIVE_SLAVE]Native slave[\LINK] Unit.[PARAGRAPH:1]If you are at war with a Native tribe, it's wise to look at the traits of the Native [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]leader[COLOR_REVERT]. These attributes show the strong and weak points of each Native tribe. You can see, for example, that some Natives fight well in [LINK=FEATURE_FOREST]forests[\LINK], while others are good at defending villages. All Natives get a [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]combat bonus[COLOR_REVERT] when attacking enemies in forests, jungles and taiga, so you try to stay out of those places, and scheme to draw them into the open.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Keeping Natives Happy, or Making Them Angry[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]There are many factors that influence the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]attitude[COLOR_REVERT] of a Native nation towards you. These are:[PARAGRAPH:2]The [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]character[COLOR_REVERT] of a particular Native tribe. Each tribe starts with a certain base attitude towards Europeans, and the influence of other factors varies amoung the different Native nations.[PARAGRAPH:1]The [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]overall size[COLOR_REVERT] of your colony. If your population grows, and your colonies get larger, Natives are going to see you as a threat to their way of life.[PARAGRAPH:1]The [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Proximity[COLOR_REVERT] of your settlements to theirs. If your borders lie close to their villages, and your nearby colonies are very large, they feel threatened as well.[PARAGRAPH:1]The amount of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Stolen Land[COLOR_REVERT]. If you choose to steal Native land instead of paying for it, they will remain angry for each plot you stole, until your cultural influence on that tile exceeds theirs.[PARAGRAPH:1]NOTE: They regard any plot where their cultural influence is stronger than yours, but which falls inside your borders, as "Stolen," no matter how you obtained it. See [LINK=CONCEPT_BORDERS]Borders and Culture[\LINK] for an overview of ways in which this can happen.[PARAGRAPH:1]The number of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Missions[COLOR_REVERT] your missionaries have established in their settlements also improves your relationship with them, and decreases the degree to which they feel threatened by your growing colony.[PARAGRAPH:1]Certain [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Founding Fathers[COLOR_REVERT] also improve your relationship with Natives, while others soften how much you threaten the Natives.[PARAGRAPH:1]On the other hand, if you attempt to establish a mission in a Native settlement, but fail, this can worsen your relations with that tribe.[PARAGRAPH:1]The [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]leaders[COLOR_REVERT] of the [LINK=CIVILIZATION_FRANCE]French colonies[\LINK] automatically receive a bonus in their relationship with Natives.[PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Trading[COLOR_REVERT] with Natives also improves your friendship. The best way to win the Natives' sympathy is by giving them money or goods as gifts.[PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Rejecting[COLOR_REVERT] trade proposals Natives make when they visit your colony also can harm your relations with them.[PARAGRAPH:1]Certain [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Diplomatic Choices[COLOR_REVERT] you make affect their attitude as well. If you are both at war with a common enemy, or if you declared war on that enemy when that Native tribe asked you to, your relations will improve, but if you refuse to start a war at their request, if you trade with their enemies, or if you have ever declared war on a nation they consider to be their friends, your relations will suffer. If you have declared war on a Native nation in the past, or if you have razed their settlements, they will remain angry about that as well.[PARAGRAPH:1]The period of time during which you've been at [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]peace[COLOR_REVERT] with them also influences the attitude of the Natives towards you.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are also some [LINK=CONCEPT_EVENTS]random events[\LINK] where you can make choices that influence your relations with them for better or worse.
TEXT.French: [H1]INDIGÈNES[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Au début de la partie, le Nouveau Monde appartient aux indigènes. La majeure partie du monde dépend d'eux. Ainsi, si vous désirez sortir en tête de la course à la colonisation, il faudra les soudoyer, négocier avec eux, voire les affronter, afin d'asseoir sur ces terres nouvelles votre propre suprématie.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Interagir avec les indigènes[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Le Nouveau Monde est habité par huit peuples indigènes qu'il vous sera possible de rencontrer. Tous possèdent une culture et une mentalité propres, ainsi qu'un ressenti particulier vis-à-vis des étrangers. En début de partie, vous êtes automatiquement en paix avec les indigènes et pouvez circuler librement au sein de leurs territoires. Un sage dirigeant saura très tôt fraterniser avec les indigènes, sachant que nombre d'entre eux honoreront sa colonie de présents précieux en gage d'amitié. [PARAGRAPH:2]Vous pouvez également recevoir des présents de la part des indigènes en envoyant une unité dans l'une de leurs colonies, puis en sélectionnant l'ordre "Parler au chef".
